overview_of_class: This course examines the history of Russian drama through a selective reading and analysis of some of the major Russian plays of the19th and the 20th centuries. It will focus on the history of dramatic literature rather than that of theatrical performances. We will trace the development of Russian drama through its various historical phases, starting with Pushkin's adaptation of the Neoclassicist tradition and ending with Vampilov's modernist experimentation with absurd and fragmentation. We will evaluate the potentials and problems of reading plays in the theoretical framework of dramaturgical writings of both Russia and the West, and inquire into such prevalent elements of the Russian dramatic tradition as grotesque, fantastic, naturalism and tragicomedy. Through our selected texts we will explore both the process in which the lineage of the Russian dramatic composition was formed and transformed, and the interpenetration of this literary tradition with the dramatic heritages of other nations of the world.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students are not expected to have any prior knowledge of Russian language, though they will learn the basics of Russian proper names to facilitate their reading. Graduate students are encouraged to read the primary texts in the Russian original. All lectures, discussions, readings and assignments will be in English.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This course will help students develop a systematic understanding and critical appreciation of Russian dramatic writing. Students will also be able to improve their capacities of close reading and analytical writing on literary topics.
